awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: Communications in Ultra-Low-Rate Regime: Fundamental Limits, Code Constructions, and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Wireless networks have become an integral part of our society by connecting billions of users around the globe. The next generation wireless networks, known as 5G, are expected to deliver orders of magnitude higher data rates to an ever-increasing number of devices. The fundamental limits on how much networks can be pushed towards these advancements are determined by the amount of available wireless bands. To this end, two extremes of wireless communications have become increasingly important, namely, narrowband and wideband. The narrowband communication, using a small band of frequencies, enables connectivity of thousands of devices, such as everyday objects in Internet-of-Things (IoT) networks, to a single cell tower. Wideband communications, using large swaths of frequencies, at extremely high frequencies is the key enabling technology for delivering ultra-high data rates to 5G mobile users. In both of these scenarios, individual bits of information are assigned extremely low power for communication resulting in bit-wise wireless channels with low capacity. This introduces a new array of fundamental problems with respect to communications over low-capacity channels that is the focus of this project. The results of this project will contribute to the foundation of information and coding theory as well as the development of wireless networks that can achieve the ultimate limits of narrowband and wideband communications.

Recently, the wireless standards entity, 3GPP, has introduced new protocols into the standard in order to integrate IoT into the cellular network. A major feature of these protocols is to deploy ultra-low-rate communications in order to address diverse requirements of IoT networks. Such low-rate communication is enabled in the standard by simply allowing a large number of block repetitions, which could be extremely suboptimal from the channel coding perspective. A similar situation arises in wideband scenarios. Wideband channels can essentially provide high data rates, in terms of bits per second. However, individual coded bits experience extremely low signal-to-noise ratios, due to limited signal power and larger attenuations in higher frequencies. In light of the emerging applications in these two extremes of wireless communications, the investigators aim at a comprehensive investigation of channel coding in the low-capacity regime. The specific objectives in this project are as follows: (1) Provide a precise framework for channel coding at low capacity, and characterize fundamental non-asymptotic laws for channel coding in this regime; (2)  Develop techniques for the non-asymptotic analysis of wireless wideband and millimeter wave systems; (3) Investigate state-of-the-art codes, including their construction, performance, and efficient decoding, for adaptation to low-rate regimes; (4) Construct efficient concatenated coding schemes including coded repetition and concatenation with low-rate algebraic codes, given diverse requirements of low-capacity applications. Consequently, this project develops a formal connection between information theory, coding theory, and wireless communications resulting in a mathematically precise interface between these areas to address the challenges of narrowband and wideband wireless systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main research problem considered in this project is to understand the fundamental limits of channel coding over channels that have a very low capacity and design practical codes that approach those limits. Along these lines, the project had 5 major goals:

1) Provide a precise framework for channel coding at low capacity, and characterize fundamental non-asymptotic laws for channel coding in this regime;

2)  Develop techniques for the non-asymptotic analysis of wireless wideband systems; 

3) Derive capacity and non-asymptotic limits of mmWave channels under realistic models;
Investigate state-of-the-art codes, including their practical construction, performance, and efficient decoding, for adaptation to low-rate regimes;

4) Construct practical coding schemes including coded repetition and concatenation with low-rate algebraic codes, given diverse requirements of low-capacity applications.

5) Use the ideas developed in Goals 1-4 (also developed new ideas) to design schemes for communication in other scenarios with low-rate constraints; e.g. in distributed machine learning scenarios (such as federated learning) where it's important to send short messages to the server, or in data compression where it is important to compress data as much as possible with reasonable distortion.


To summarize the scientific outcomes of the project, we are delighted to report that we have made substantial progress with respect to all the five goals detailed above: 

(1) We have provided a precise definition and principled framework for communication at low capacity. Accordingly, we have fully characterized the fundamental non-asymptotic limits of low-capacity communication for several channels that are commonly used in practice. 
(2) We further derived fundamental principles for designing practical codes in the low-capacity regime and investigated how some of the well-known codes (such as polar or LDPC codes) behave according to these principles. Using these principles, we have devised practical coding schemes for the low-capacity scenario. This was done using a specific class code called Reed-Muller sub-codes, for which we proposed new decoding algorithms in the low-rate regime. In general, this research has rendered a general framework toward efficient decoding of RM codes in the low-rate regime.

(3)  We designed schemes for communication in distributed machine learning scenarios (such as federated learning). One key challenge in distributed learning is the communication among the users (and the server); and oftentimes in practice, the communication overhead acts as the bottleneck in the overall systems performance, and it often leads to very stringent constraints on the number of bits available per message to be sent (similar to the low-capacity regime). Our efforts led to provably efficient methods for several scenarios in multi-agent learning with significantly reduced communication overhead. including multi-agent reinforcement learning and federated learning.
(4) Finally, in the last year of this project, we considered data compression at the ultra-low-rate regime. This is very much aligned with the original goals of this project as data compression and channel coding are considered dual problems with respect to each other. In this line of work, we focused on very practical row-rate compression schemes for image data and used machine learning-based techniques for the compression and proposed schemes that significantly improve upon the state-of-the-art in terms of perceptual and semantic fidelity as measures of distortion.
To summarize the broader impacts of the project, we are happy to report the following: 
1) This project will impact the way we think about wireless communication when the transmission medium is extremely noisy. There are numerous examples of real-world situations ranging from Internet-of-Things (with many users sharing the same medium) or deep-space communication. This project has laid the foundations for communication in low-rate settings and has proposed several practical schemes. Apart from communication and channel coding, the ideas of this project were extended to distributed machine-learning scenarios, where many users have to communicate to the same server and need to communicate using a small number of bits, as well as data compression at ultra-low rates. We believe that the ideas developed in this project will be useful in any scenario where communication among users is needed with stringent conditions on the number of bits to be transmitted.  The results of this project will contribute to the foundation of information and coding theory as well as the development of wireless networks that can achieve the ultimate limits of narrowband and wideband communications.

2) We held the 2023 IEEE North-American School of Information Theory (NASIT) at Penn, and the PI (Hamed Hassani) was one of the main organizers. The school was very successful in bringing together around 100 PhD students and researchers with 10 invited talks on topics relevant to this project (and other topics). 

3) This project successfully trained two Ph.D. students: one defended a few months ago (which received an excellent rating from the committee) and the other will defend next year. The project also contributed to the training of a postdoctoral researcher who has now become an assistant professor at the North Carolina State University.
